description: Master mechanics, thermodynamics, materials, and mechanical systems design

chapters.title: Mechanical Fundamentals
chapters.description: Core principles of mechanics, forces, and energy

lessons.title: Units and Dimensions
objectives: Understand SI and Imperial unit systems

content.introduction: Proper understanding of units and dimensions is essential for all engineering calculations. This lesson covers the fundamental and derived quantities used in mechanical engineering.

sections.title: SI Fundamental Units
sections.content: The International System (SI) uses 7 fundamental units: meter (length), kilogram (mass), second (time), ampere (electric current), kelvin (temperature), mole (amount), candela (luminous intensity).

sections.title: Mechanical Derived Units
sections.content: Force (Newton = kg·m/s²), Pressure (Pascal = N/m²), Energy (Joule = N·m), Power (Watt = J/s)

sections.title: Dimensional Analysis
sections.content: Use dimensional analysis to check equations and convert units. Dimensions of both sides must match for a valid equation.

formulas.description: Definition of Newton in SI units

lessons.title: Vectors and Forces
objectives: Add and subtract vectors graphically and analytically

content.introduction: Forces are vector quantities - they have both magnitude and direction. Understanding vector operations is fundamental to all mechanical engineering analysis.

sections.title: Scalars vs Vectors
sections.content: Scalars have magnitude only (mass, time, energy). Vectors have magnitude and direction (force, velocity, acceleration).

sections.title: Vector Addition
sections.content: Vectors can be added using head-to-tail method, parallelogram method, or component method. Resultant is the vector sum.

sections.title: Force Components
sections.content: A force can be resolved into rectangular components: F_x = F·cos(θ), F_y = F·sin(θ)

problems.title: Force Components
problems.description: A 100N force acts at 30° to the horizontal. Calculate its x and y components.

content.introduction: A particle is in equilibrium when the resultant of all forces acting on it is zero. This is fundamental to structural analysis and machine design.

sections.title: Equilibrium Conditions
sections.content: For 2D: ΣFx = 0 and ΣFy = 0. For 3D: Add ΣMz = 0.

sections.title: Free-Body Diagrams
sections.content: A FBD shows all forces acting on a body. Include known forces, reactions, and weight (if significant).

sections.title: Solving Equilibrium Problems
sections.content: Draw FBD, apply equilibrium equations, solve for unknowns. Check results by substituting back.

problems.title: Simple Equilibrium
problems.description: A 100N weight hangs from two cables at 45° angles. Find the tension in each cable.

lessons.title: Moments and Couples
objectives: Calculate moments using scalar and vector methods

content.introduction: Moment (torque) measures the turning effect of a force. Understanding moments is essential for analyzing rotating machinery and structural stability.

sections.title: Moment of a Force
sections.content: Moment = Force × perpendicular distance (M = F × d). Units: N·m or lb·ft.

sections.title: Varignon's Theorem
sections.content: The moment of a force about a point equals the sum of moments of its components about the same point.

sections.title: Couples
sections.content: A couple is two equal, opposite, parallel forces. The moment of a couple is M = F × d, independent of reference point.

problems.title: Moment Calculation
problems.description: A 50N force is applied at the end of a 0.8m wrench. Calculate the moment about the bolt.

lessons.title: Basic Thermodynamic Concepts
objectives: Understand properties and states of matter

content.introduction: Thermodynamics studies energy, heat, and their transformations. It's fundamental to engines, refrigerators, HVAC systems, and power plants.

sections.title: System and Surroundings
sections.content: System: the region of interest. Surroundings: everything else. Boundary: separates them (can be real or imaginary, fixed or moving).

sections.title: Properties and State
sections.content: Properties describe a system's condition (pressure, temperature, volume). State is defined by property values.

sections.title: Processes and Cycles
sections.content: Process: change from one state to another. Cycle: series of processes returning to initial state.

lessons.title: First Law of Thermodynamics
objectives: State and apply the First Law
Calculate heat, work, and internal energy changes

content.introduction: The First Law (Conservation of Energy) states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. For thermodynamic systems: ΔU = Q - W.

sections.title: Energy Balance
sections.content: For a closed system: ΔU = Q - W, where ΔU is internal energy change, Q is heat added to system, W is work done by system.

sections.title: Work and Heat
sections.content: Work: energy transfer by force across boundary (PdV work). Heat: energy transfer due to temperature difference.

sections.title: Specific Forms
sections.content: For ideal gases: ΔU = m·cv·ΔT, W = ∫PdV. For steady flow: Q̇ - Ẇ = ṁ·Δh + ΔKE + ΔPE

formulas.description: Internal energy change for ideal gas

problems.title: First Law Application
problems.description: 2000J of heat is added to a gas while it does 500J of work. Find the change in internal energy.

lessons.title: Second Law of Thermodynamics
objectives: State the Second Law in various forms
Analyze heat engine and refrigerator cycles

content.introduction: The Second Law establishes limits on energy conversions and defines entropy. It explains why heat flows spontaneously from hot to cold and why perfect efficiency is impossible.

sections.title: Second Law Statements
sections.content: Kelvin-Planck: No heat engine can convert all heat to work. Clausius: No refrigerator can transfer heat from cold to hot without work input.

sections.title: Entropy
sections.content: Entropy (S) measures disorder. For reversible processes: ΔS = Q/T. Total entropy of isolated system always increases.

sections.title: Carnot Cycle
sections.content: Maximum theoretical efficiency for a heat engine operating between two temperatures: η = 1 - Tc/Th

problems.title: Carnot Efficiency
problems.description: A heat engine operates between 400K and 300K. Calculate the maximum theoretical efficiency.

lessons.title: Heat Transfer Mechanisms
objectives: Calculate heat transfer for composite walls

content.introduction: Heat transfer occurs through three mechanisms: conduction (molecular contact), convection (fluid motion), and radiation (electromagnetic waves).

sections.title: Conduction
sections.content: Fourier's Law: q = -k·A·dT/dx. Heat flows from hot to cold through materials.

sections.title: Convection
sections.content: Newton's Law: q = h·A·ΔT. Depends on fluid properties, flow velocity, and surface geometry.

sections.title: Radiation
sections.content: Stefan-Boltzmann Law: q = ε·σ·A·T⁴. All objects above absolute zero emit thermal radiation.

lessons.title: Stress and Strain
objectives: Analyze material properties from stress-strain curves

content.introduction: Mechanics of materials studies how components deform and fail under loads. Understanding stress and strain is essential for safe structural design.

sections.title: Stress
sections.content: Stress (σ) = Force/Area. Normal stress acts perpendicular to surface, shear stress acts parallel. Units: Pa (N/m²) or psi.

sections.title: Strain
sections.content: Strain (ε) = deformation/original dimension. Normal strain is elongation, shear strain is angular distortion.

sections.title: Hooke's Law
sections.content: Within elastic limit: σ = E·ε, where E is Young's modulus. For shear: τ = G·γ

content.introduction: Beams are structural members that carry transverse loads. Bending causes compression on one side and tension on the other.

sections.title: Bending Theory
sections.content: Pure bending: M = σ·I/y = E·I/R. Stress varies linearly from neutral axis. Maximum stress at outermost fibers.

sections.title: Section Modulus
sections.content: Section modulus Z = I/y_max. Required section modulus: Z_required = M_max/σ_allowable.

sections.title: Shear and Moment Diagrams
sections.content: Draw shear and moment diagrams to find maximum values. Use area-moment method or differential relationships.

content.introduction: Torsion occurs when a shaft transmits torque. Circular shafts experience pure shear stress, with maximum stress at the outer surface.

sections.title: Torsion Formula
sections.content: For circular shafts: τ = T·r/J. J is polar moment of inertia. Maximum at r = outer radius.

sections.title: Angle of Twist
sections.content: θ = T·L/(G·J). L is length, G is shear modulus. Twist varies along shaft length.

sections.title: Power Transmission
sections.content: Power P = T·ω, where ω = 2πN/60. For design, use rated torque and service factor.

problems.title: Shaft Design
problems.description: A solid shaft transmits 5 kN·m torque. If allowable shear stress is 40 MPa, find minimum diameter.

lessons.title: Mechanical Properties of Materials
objectives: Compare properties of different material classes

content.introduction: Material properties determine how a material behaves under various conditions. Understanding these properties is crucial for proper material selection.

sections.title: Key Properties
sections.content: Strength (yield, ultimate), ductility, toughness, hardness, stiffness (Young's modulus), fatigue strength, creep resistance.

sections.title: Stress-Strain Curve Regions
sections.content: Elastic region (linear, recoverable), yield point, plastic region (permanent deformation), ultimate tensile strength, fracture.

sections.title: Testing Methods
sections.content: Tensile test gives stress-strain curve. Hardness tests (Brinell, Rockwell) correlate with strength. Impact test measures toughness.

content.introduction: Material selection balances performance requirements with cost, manufacturability, and sustainability. Systematic approaches improve decision-making.

sections.title: Selection Criteria
sections.content: Mechanical requirements (strength, stiffness), environmental exposure, cost constraints, availability, and recyclability.

sections.title: Ashby Charts
sections.content: Material property charts show performance indices. Plot candidate materials to identify the optimal choice.

sections.title: Trade-offs
sections.content: Strength vs weight, cost vs performance, stiffness vs damping. No single material excels in all properties.
